data.title: Size matters: tall players are hitting the heights
data.meta_description: SKILL, hand-eye co-ordination, determination and mental strength all count in golf. Does size count as well? It certainly does. Consider this: only three men of 5ft 9in or less have won a major
data.text:
SKILL, hand-eye co-ordination, determination and mental strength all count in golf. Does size count as well? It certainly does.

Consider this: only three men of 5ft 9in or less have won a major championship in the past ten years — Rich Beem, who is 5ft 8in, the 2002 US PGA; Mike Weir, who is 5ft 9in, the 2003 Masters; and Justin Leonard, who is 5ft 9in, the 1997 Open.

The shortest man to win the US Open since Corey Pavin, who is 5ft 8in, did so in 1995 is Michael Campbell, who is 5ft 10in. Only two men of less than 6ft have won the Masters in the past decade — José Maria Olazábal in 1999 and Weir in 2003 — and only three men
